### Abstract  
**Integrating Islamic Spirituality to Foster Resilience and Post-Traumatic Growth in Community Mental Health and Education**  

In the Middle East, communities face intersecting challenges of displacement, conflict, and socio-economic uncertainty that strain both mental health systems and everyday educational and social settings. At the same time, Islamic spirituality offers a rich tradition of meaning-making, belonging, and resilience that can serve as a resource for post-traumatic growth and psychological flourishing. This presentation draws on mixed-methods research conducted after the 2020 Beirut Port Explosion, as well as subsequent programmatic work in Iraq and Gaza, to examine how spiritually integrated practices can complement existing healthcare and community support systems.  

The first part of the presentation summarizes empirical evidence linking Islamic concepts such as tawakkul (trust in God), sabr (patience), and shukr (gratitude) with measurable indicators of resilience, well-being, and growth following adversity. These findings are situated within broader literature on post-traumatic growth and positive psychology, highlighting parallels and unique contributions from Islamic perspectives.  

The second part addresses cultural considerations in adapting these insights across diverse Arab contexts. Particular attention is given to the role of schools, mosques, and community-based organizations as sites where spirituality and psychosocial support intersect. Through case studies of teacher training workshops, entrepreneurship programs, and community rebuilding initiatives, the presentation identifies both opportunities (such as fostering belonging, narrative reframing, and cooperative learning) and barriers (such as stigma, lack of trained facilitators, and institutional resistance) to integrating Islamic spirituality into practical interventions.  

Finally, the presentation explores future directions for research, education, and clinical practice in Islamic psychology. These include developing evidence-based curricula that align with both Islamic epistemologies and contemporary mental health frameworks, designing training-of-trainers models for educators and practitioners, and building cross-regional networks of scholars and practitioners to advance the field.  

By situating Islamic spirituality as a resource for resilience and post-traumatic growth, this contribution seeks to bridge research, practice, and cultural context. It argues that integrating these perspectives is not only culturally responsive but essential to addressing the unique psychosocial needs of the Middle East today.

In doing so, it offers a model for spiritually integrated mental health support in educational settings across the Middle East.

Symposium Overview 
The field of Islamic psychology has traditionally concentrated on creating models and treatment approaches for individual therapy and clinical settings. However, there is a growing demand for Islamically integrated interventions in a wider range of mental health services within hospitals, addiction rehabilitation centers, schools, colleges, social work agencies, etc.

There is also a need to expand the scope of Islamically grounded psychological interventions to include diverse populations beyond just adults. This scope should encompass adolescents, young adults, and the elderly. Such interventions can be applied in various settings, including outpatient facilities, group treatment environments, forensic settings, behavioral health programs, religious contexts (such as mosques and Ministries of Awqaf), as well as in non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

With the increasing interest in Qatar, the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) region, and the broader Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region, this symposium seeks to engage local and regional communities in an interactive discussion about the current landscape and future directions for integrating Islamic and spiritual psychological approaches in various mental health settings.
